utterances: Hi, Neal.

I'm a professional speaker and comedian.

Because people want, I guess, a little break from their troubles.
I think they want a little break from their troubles, and I think that they also want to talk or want to find out the origins of their stress.

I work with a guy name Steve Rizzo years ago.
And he said, during good times, people want to laugh, but during bad times they really need us to make them laugh.
And it does occur to me - going back to that e-mail about the businesses that it did well on the Great Depression, well, entertainment sure did pretty well during the Great Depression.

Yes.

Let's talk now with Chris(ph).
And Chris is with us from Montague in Michigan.
That's right, Neal.
I, along with my partner, run a volunteer all- organic, all-local, all humanely raised animal products, farmer's market, a year-round market.

And we are seeing a lot of people sort of - the downturn of the economy and the increased stress seemed to have been like the tipping point for a lot of people to actually sit down and think about their diet.
And, you know, people shop at our mart.
We have the highest quality food available in Michigan.
I don't mean to challenge you, but they might be thinking about their wallets, too.
Well, of course.
But here is the deal.
The cost - our food cost about the same as organic in the supermarket, but it's much fresher and you get to know the farmer.
But the real savings comes from - it keeps longer and your health gets better.
And in Michigan, we're in the middle, which many people called the depression, not really a recession, and we are in such a bit of trouble.
And that people loose their health care very often in these job-downsizing situations.
And so, one of the best things I can do to save money is actually eat healthy food and so, people are beginning to get that.

And the number of people coming to our farmer's market, which is year round -and we're actually in partnership with the hospital, we actually hold it inside the building owned by a hospital, are coming because they want to have healthy lives.
And see that saving them lots of money.
Food prices, in general, farmer's products of corn that sort of thing, we - those prices are very strong across the entire country.
And I guess, you're also benefiting from the shop local trends.

Yes.
It's - and you should understand that the sort of long-distance food system - a company here in Michigan spends twice as much shipping tomatoes to Michigan as it does buying them.
You know, these are oil intensive, you know, the corn, the wheat, these big crops are very oil intensive.
Our farmers use them because they're organic, do not use petroleum inputs.
So their costs are actually much lower, and so their prizes are now more and more competitive.

That's David Plouffe, the president's top political adviser, who points out that in the last couple of weeks, Barack Obama and John Boehner spent more time together on the phone and in-person than they ever had before.
When you go through a process like this, like the president and the speaker did, you'll learn a lot about the other person and you do build up trust.
And you understand that you do have the ability even if it comes at the last moment to find common ground.
Mara Liasson, NPR News, Washington.
In rural Washington state people gathered this past weekend to celebrate the country's most famous unsolved hijacking.

Cooper seized a jetliner, received a ransom, and parachuted out somewhere over the southwestern part of the state.
